conclusion: Consider factors such as power of the car, collision dynamics, and deflection effects.
The toy car (A) is entering from the lower right corner with an initial velocity.
The power of the car is moderate, not enough to move heavy objects but can push lighter ones.
The car will first collide with the marble due to its proximity.
Upon hitting the marble, the car will transfer some of its kinetic energy to the marble, causing it to move.
The marble, being round and smooth, will roll away from the point of impact.
After colliding with the marble, the car will likely be deflected slightly to the left due to the angle of impact.
The car will then continue moving towards the blocks.
The car will hit the blue block first, which is closest to its path after the deflection.
The blue block, being a cube, will not roll away but may slide a bit depending on the friction between the block and the table surface.
After hitting the blue block, the car will be further deflected and may hit the yellow block next.
The yellow block will resist movement due to its shape and weight, causing the car to lose more momentum.
The car might then hit the red block, which is positioned close to the yellow block.
After colliding with multiple blocks, the car will lose most of its kinetic energy.
The car will eventually come to a stop near the red block, as this area has the highest concentration of blocks that will absorb the remaining energy.
